Editor’s choice paper High-temperature water-gas shift over Fe/Ce/Co spinel catalysts: Study of the promotional effect of Ce and Co Devaiah Damma Thirupathi Boningari Panagiotis G. Smirniotis ⁎ Chemical Engineering Program, College of Engineering and Applied Science, University of Cincinnati, Cincinnati, OH 45221-0012, USA Chemical Engineering Program College of Engineering and Applied Science University of Cincinnati Cincinnati OH 45221-0012 USA ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract A set of Fe/Ce/Co ferrite spinels was synthesized and characterized to investigate the effect of Ce and Co atomic contents in the catalyst on the high-temperature water-gas shift (HT-WGS) performance. It was found that both the Ce and Co atomic compositions in the Fe/Ce/Co catalyst have a significant influence on the surface and structural properties and thereby HT-WGS activity. The Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5) exhibited the best activity owing to preferable properties among the catalysts with other Ce and Co atomic contents. Besides, it showed an excellent time-on-stream (TOS) stability in HT-WGS for 100h of reaction even at lower steam to CO ratio of 1.5. XRD results suggested that Ce and Co co-doping could make the lattice strain in the magnetite lattice because of difference in the ionic sizes of Fe and dopants. Raman spectroscopy demonstrated that the lattice disorder was introduced with the addition of Ce and Co. The magnitude of the lattice strain/disorder depends on the promoters’ (Ce and Co) atomic composition in the catalyst. Our H2-TPR findings indicate that the degree of reduction for hematite-to-magnetite conversion increased until the Ce and Co atomic concentration reached to 1.0 and 1.5, respectively. The XPS analysis proves that both Ce and Co as dopants have the ability to facilitate the surface Fe3+ ↔Fe2+ redox cycle over the catalysts because of their redox nature (Ce4+/Ce3+, Co2+/Co3+). We observed the changes in the quantity of surface Fe3+/Fe2+ ratio as a function of the Ce and Co atomic contents. The results also revealed that the surface area, lattice strain/disorder, reducibility, and surface Fe3+/Fe2+ redox pair were the decisive factors for the HT-WGS reaction. A combination of techniques demonstrated that there is a strong synergistic interaction between Fe and dopants (Ce and Co) in the Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5) which could enhance its surface area, lattice strain/disorder, surface Fe3+/Fe2+ redox capability, and thus leading to the elevated HT-WGS activity among other catalysts. XPS investigations on the spent Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5) after 100h of reaction show that the catalyst remains in magnetite phase like the reduced one and is not reduced or oxidized during reaction. Our TEM images confirm that the Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5) catalyst particles are not agglomerating/sintering during the TOS study which is an important characteristic for its long term stability. Keywords Ferrite spinels High-temperature water-gas shift Lattice strain/disorder Synergistic interaction 1 Introduction The high-temperature water-gas shift (HT-WGS) reaction is one of the promising processes for hydrogen production in the industry. Until the present, the most successful commercial catalytic formulation for the HT-WGS is based on Cu-promoted iron–chromium mixed oxide. Generally, 8–14wt.% of Cr2O3 can be incorporated into the commercial catalyst as a textural promoter to inhibit sintering of the active phase of catalyst (Fe3O4) during the reaction [1–3]. However, it is well-known that Cr3+ converts to Cr6+ during the reaction, which is highly toxic to human organs due to its potent carcinogen nature [4,5]. Hence, there has been growing interest in the design and the development of Cr-free Fe-based HT-WGS catalysts owing to environmental and health concerns related to chromium [6,7]. Enormous attempts have been made in recent years to substitute the Cr in Fe-based catalysts with other promoters while maintaining the high activity and stability for HT-WGS [5,8–11]. For instance, Araujo and Rangel have replaced the Cr with Al and claimed the Fe–Al–Cu catalyst has similar HT-WGS activity compared to the commercial Fe–Cr–Cu catalyst [10]. For the iron-based catalysts, it was proposed that the catalytic active sites are pairs of Fe3+–Fe2+ cations that participate in the WGS reaction [12–14]. The addition of redox component into iron oxide lattice is known to promote the Fe3+ ↔Fe2+ redox cycle in the catalyst which can significantly increase the catalytic activity in WGS through the redox mechanism. Among the various redox dopants, CeO2 (ceria) is expected to be the most promising for the development of Cr-free Fe-based catalysts as it can facilitate the Fe3+/Fe2+ redox couple through its unique Ce4+/Ce3+ redox pair [15–17]. It is well known that the sintering effect of Fe-based oxide catalysts during the WGS reaction typically result in a loss of catalytic activity. The incorporation of ceria also improved the thermal stability of iron-based catalysts [9,11,18]. In one such approach, Liu et al. synthesized Fe–Al–Ce catalyst and examined for the HT-WGS which exhibited a comparable catalytic activity and thermal stability to that of the commercial Fe–Cr catalyst [11]. Our previous study also demonstrates that the Fe/Ce-modified ferrite is one of the promising systems for HT-WGS [15]. Alternatively, cobalt oxide (Co3O4) has been reported as an effective promoter for ceria-based catalysts [19] as well as iron-based catalysts towards HT-WGS [20]. The coexistence of Co2+–Co3+ ion pairs in the crystal structure of cobalt oxide was found to be responsible for its promotional effect [21]. Therefore, co-doping of Ce- and Co-promoters into iron oxide is expected to be a promising Cr-free catalyst for the HT-WGS reaction. Besides, previous works suggest that the promoters’ composition in the catalyst can significantly tune the structural properties which in turn catalytic performance [22]. For example, Meshkani et al. studied the effect of Fe/Al and Fe/Cu weight ratio of the Fe–Al–Cu and the catalyst with Fe/Al=10 and Fe/Cu=5wt. ratios found to be exhibit the highest activity among the others at different Al and Cu contents [23]. Our recent publication also proved the notable influence of the Ce and Cr atomic concentrations on the physicochemical properties thereby HT-WGS performance of the Fe–Ce–Cr catalyst [24]. However, to the best of our knowledge, there was no report concerning the effect of the Ce and Co atomic compositions on the Fe/Ce/Co catalyst which is necessary to accomplish better structural properties and thus high catalytic activity and stability in HT-WGS. The main purpose of the present study is to get an insight into the influence of the Ce and Co atomic contents on the physicochemical properties and in turn HT-WGS performance of the Fe/Ce/Co catalyst. In order to understand the effect of Ce and Co atomic compositions on the Fe/Ce/Co comprehensively, the catalyst was synthesized with varying Ce (at fixed Co content) and Co (at fixed Ce content) atomic concentrations and characterized by applying various techniques. We observed the considerable changes in the catalyst structural/surface properties and thereby activity towards HT-WGS as a function of the both Ce and Co atomic compositions. Our XRD and Raman results suggest that the incorporation of Ce and Co into iron oxide could result the lattice strain/disorder in the catalyst and its concentration is proportional to the WGS activity. Our H2-TPR findings indicate that both the Ce- and Co-promoters have the ability to change the reducibility of the Fe/Ce/Co catalyst. In particular, the atomic composition of both the dopants has a distinctive influence on the surface Fe3+/Fe2+ redox cycle and furthermore on catalytic activity owing to their redox nature (Ce4+/Ce3+, Co2+/Co3+), which was demonstrated by XPS. Combined catalyst characterizations also revealed the synergistic interaction between Fe and dopants in the catalyst that altered with the Ce and Co atomic contents. The HT-WGS performance of the Fe/Ce/Co catalysts correlated with their structural modifications due to varying the Ce and Co atomic concentrations. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The Fe/Ce/Co catalysts with varied Ce and Co atomic contents were synthesized by a co-precipitation method. First, Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, Ce(NH4)2(NO3)6, and Co(NO3)2·6H2O precursor salts at desired atomic ratio of Fe:Ce:Co were dissolved in distilled water and mixed together under continuous stirring at room temperature. Subsequently, aqueous NH3 was added into the above metal ions solution mixture drop by drop until the pH value reached 9.0, where the formation of a precipitate was noticed. Next, the precipitate was filtered and washed with deionized water and dried in an oven at 100°C for 12h. Finally, the dried solid product was calcined at 500°C for 3h with a temperature ramp of 5°Cmin−1. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis of the catalysts was executed on a Rigaku Multiflex diffractometer equipped with a nickel-filtered Cu-Kα radiation having a wavelength of 1.54Å. The patterns were taken over a 2θ range of 20–80° with a step size of 0.02° and using a counting time of one second per point. The phase identification was made with the help of the Powder Diffraction File from the International Centre for Diffraction Data (PDF-ICDD). The average crystallite size (D) and lattice strain were determined by the Scherrer equation and the Williamson-Hall plots, respectively. The lattice parameter was estimated through a standard cubic indexation method by the intensity of the most prominent (311) peak. The elemental composition of the catalysts was measured by energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis. The Raman spectra of the catalysts were recorded in a LabRam HR800UV Raman spectrometer (Horiba Jobin-Yvon) with a liquid-nitrogen cooled charge-coupled device (CCD) detector at room temperature. The spectra were collected using an excitation laser wavelength of 632nm from an Ar+ ion laser (Spectra Physics). The laser was focused on the catalyst under the microscope with the diameter of the analyzed spot being ∼1mm. The acquisition time was adjusted according to the intensity of Raman scattering. The frequency values in wave numbers obtained from the spectra were precise to within 2cm−1. The reducibility of the catalysts was measured by H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) analysis using a gas chromatograph (Micromeritics, model AutoChem II 2920), equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The catalyst (50mg) was loaded into a quartz reactor and pre-treated in a helium gas flow at 200°C. After cooled down to room temperature, the flow was switched to 10% H2 in He and the catalyst was heated to 900°C at a rate of 5°Cmin−1. The H2 consumption during the reduction process was examined by a thermal conductivity detector. Surface areas of the catalysts were measured by N2 physisorption at liquid N2 temperature with the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method employing a Micromeritics 2010 instrument. Prior to analysis, the catalysts were degassed in vacuum at 300°C for 2h to remove the surface adsorbed residual moisture. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) experiments were conducted on a Shimadzu ESCA 3400 spectrometer using Al-Kα (1486.7eV) radiation as the excitation source at room temperature. The pressure of the catalyst chamber was maintained below 10−8 Pa to avoid a large amount of noise in the spectra from contaminants. The obtained binding energies were adjusted by referencing the spectra to the carbon (C 1s) peak at 284.6eV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were recorded on a Zeiss Libra 120 model microscope operating at 120kV. The average particle size of the catalyst was calculated over 50 particles. For the analysis, the catalyst was prepared by dispersing ultrasonically in ethanol and spread over perforated copper grids. 2.3 Catalytic activity studies HT-WGS reaction was carried out in a vertical down flow fixed-bed quartz reactor (i.d. 0.635cm) at atmospheric pressure. 0.1g of powdered catalyst was used in each test and was placed between two quartz wool plugs in the middle of the reactor. The reactor was located vertically inside a programmable tubular furnace (Electro heat systems, series HT1148S) and heated by using a temperature controller (Omega CN 2041). Before the reaction, the catalysts were reduced at 400°C for 4h using a process gas (process gas is a mixture of H2, CO, CO2 (99.9% pure gases), and water vapor) with a reductant to oxidant ratio of R=1.4 {R=([CO]+[H2])/([CO2]+[H2O])} [5,14,25]. The process gas feed was intentionally used to avoid over-reduction of the magnetite active phase to lower carbides, oxides, or metallic iron phases during the prereduction [5]. After the reduction, the reactor temperature ramped to the desired reaction temperature (475–550°C) under process gas. The deionized water was supplied through an ISCO series D pump controller and vaporized at 150°C with heating tape before entering the reactor. The resultant water vapor was mixed with reactant CO gas and fed to the reactor at steam to CO ratios of 3.5 and 1.5 with a GHSV of about 60,000h−1. The outlet gases were passed through an ice-cooled trap to condense the unreacted water from the reaction, and the product gases were subsequently analyzed by an online gas chromatograph (Gow-Mac series 550) equipped with a porapak Q column and thermal conductivity detector. The readings were collected when the reaction reached steady-state. To measure the reaction rate over each catalyst at 500°C, the experiments were conducted in order to establish differential reactor approach and mass transfer free operating conditions. The rates were calculated from the slope of XCO with WCat/FCO, where XCO is the fractional CO conversion, Wcat is the mass of the catalyst (g), and FCO is the inlet molar flow rate of CO (mol/s). The time on stream stability experiment was performed at 500°C and steam to CO ratios of 3.5 and 1.5 for 100h. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 High temperature water-gas shift activity In the present study, Fe/Ce/Co catalyst with different Ce and Co atomic contents was tested for the HT-WGS reaction. The catalytic testing was conducted from 475 to 550°C at atmospheric pressure and steam to CO ratios of 3.5 and 1.5. The fresh catalysts were firstly reduced in situ at 400°C for 4h in the presence of process gas prior to conducting the activity experiment. Irrespective of the catalyst composition, no methanation activity was observed over all the catalysts in the whole range of tested temperature during the reaction. The CO conversion values were taken when the reaction reached steady state. 3.1.1 The effect of Co atomic content on the activity of Fe/Ce/Co catalyst In order to examine the effect of Co atomic concentration on HT-WGS activity, Fe/Ce atomic ratio was kept constant at 10:1 and varied the Co atomic content from 0.5 to 2.5. Fig. S1a and b display the percentage of CO conversion as a function of Fe/Ce/Co atomic ratio with different Co atomic amounts at various temperatures and steam to CO ratio of 3.5 and 1.5, respectively. It is obvious that the CO conversion increased with an increase in Co atomic contents in the catalysts over the entire temperature range at both steam to CO ratios and reaches the maximum at Fe/Ce/Co atomic ratio of 10:1:1.5. In particular, at 550°C, the Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5) catalyst attained a CO conversion of 90 and 75, which are very close to that of the theoretical equilibrium level of CO conversion of 90.1% and 75.6% at steam to CO ratio of 3.5 and 1.5, respectively. However, with further increase in the atomic amount of Co from 1.5 to 2.0 and 2.5, the CO conversion decreased compared to that of Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5) catalyst. This indicates that the higher level of Co atomic concentration in the Fe/Ce/Co catalyst was not beneficial to promote the catalytic activity. According to the above observations, it can be concluded that an optimum Fe/Co atomic ratio of 10:1.5 is required for the best HT-WGS performance over the studied Fe/Ce/Co oxide systems. 3.1.2 The effect of Ce atomic content on the activity of Fe/Ce/Co catalyst The effect of Ce atomic composition on catalytic activity was also investigated by fixing the Fe/Co atomic ratio at 10:1.5, since Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5) catalyst was the best system in above study. Next, the Ce atomic concentration was changed either from 1.0 to 0.5 or from 1.0 to 1.5 and 2.0 in the catalyst and compared their activity with Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5) sample. The CO conversion profiles of Fe/Ce/Co catalyst with different Ce atomic contents at various temperatures and steam to CO ratio of 3.5 and 1.5 were shown in Fig. S2a and b, respectively. It can be seen that the CO conversion decreases either with decreasing or with increasing the atomic amount of Ce from 1.0 in the catalyst at both steam to CO ratios. This result suggests that there is a balance existing between Fe and Ce at Fe/Ce=10:1 in the Fe/Ce/Co catalyst to maintain high activity for the HT-WGS reaction. This is also in harmony with our previous work, where the maximum WGS activity was obtained over the Fe–Ce–Cr catalyst at Fe/Ce atomic ratio of 10:1 [24]. To further clarify the effect of Co and Ce atomic contents on the activity of Fe/Ce/Co catalysts, the CO conversion rate (rCO) of the WGS reaction was also investigated at 500°C by varying the catalyst mass (Wcat, g) and keeping the molar flow rate of CO gas (FCO, mol/s) at constant. The variation of the fractional CO conversion (XCO) with the Wcat/FCO for the Fe/Ce/Co catalyst at different Co and Ce atomic amounts was plotted in Fig. 1 a and b, respectively. The graphs represent the linear dependence of the XCO on the W/FCO over all the catalysts. The rate of CO conversion in WGS (mol/gs) over each catalyst was determined from the slope of their respective linear plot and the corresponding values were shown in Table 2. The results revealed that the CO conversion rate over the Fe/Ce/Co catalyst increases when the Co and Ce atomic concentration increased from 0.5 to 1.5 and 0.5 to 1.0, respectively and decreases with further increasing the dopants atomic contents. Thus, the Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5) exhibits a higher reaction rate in WGS than those of the other catalysts at different Co and Ce atomic amounts. This fact again proves that it has the highest HT-WGS activity among the others samples which could be due to the strong synergistic interaction between Fe and dopants (Co and Ce) in the catalyst. In conclusion, Co and Ce are the good promoters for Fe/Ce/Co catalyst for HT-WGS if the dopants atomic concentrations are not beyond the 1.5 and 1.0, respectively. In order to explain these activity trends of Fe/Ce/Co catalyst with different Co and Ce atomic contents in HT-WGS reaction, which is a structure-sensitive reaction [24], the structural and surface properties will be discussed. 3.1.3 The role of Ce on the activity of Fe/Ce/Co catalyst In order to understand the importance of Ce, the activity of Fe/Ce/Co catalyst was determined by substituting the Ce with other rare-earth elements (La, Pr, and Sm) and corresponding results are shown in Fig. 2 . It is interesting to note that the replacement of Ce with other rare-earth elements resulted in a significant decrease in CO conversion during the reaction in the temperature range of 475–550°C at steam to CO ratio of 3.5. This result clearly indicates that the presence of Ce in the Fe/Ce/Co catalyst is propitiously contributed the higher HT-WGS activity among the other Fe/M/Co (M=La, Pr, and Sm) samples. 3.1.4 Long-term time on stream stability of Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5) catalyst The Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5) catalyst was chosen to study the time-on-stream stability since it is the best catalytic system among the other catalysts with different Ce and Co atomic compositions. Fig. 3 depicts the CO conversion as a function of the time (hour) at steam to CO ratios of both 3.5 and 1.5. Surprisingly, the Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5) catalyst showed a stable WGS performance for 100h runtime without any methane produced at both steam to CO ratios. 3.2 X-ray diffraction XRD was utilized to ascertain the phase purity and structural parameters of Fe/Ce/Co catalysts at different Co and Ce atomic contents. No diffraction lines were observed in the XRD patterns of all calcined (fresh) catalysts (not shown). This result indicates the poor crystalline structure of the samples in a fresh state that were beyond the detection ability of XRD. Subsequently, all the Fe/Ce/Co catalysts were reduced using process gas which was the same as that used for catalyst treatment before the WGS and performed the XRD measurements over reduced catalysts. The obtained diffractograms of reduced Fe/Ce/Co catalyst with different Co and Ce atomic contents are presented in Fig. 4 a and b, respectively. The diffraction peaks indexed with (220), (311), (400), (422), (511), and (440) planes in all the reduced catalysts were assigned to magnetite (Fe3O4) phase of iron oxide (JCPDS 01-088-0315) [24]. These results unambiguously confirm the formation of Fe3O4 phase during the reduction process which could be the active phase for WGS. It can be seen that besides the magnetite phase, the peaks corresponding to CeO2 phase (JCPDS-340394) were clearly observed for Fe/Ce/Co (10:1.5:1.5) and Fe/Ce/Co (10:2:1.5) catalysts [26,27]. Meanwhile, the Co3O4 phase (JCPDS 43-1003) can only emerge in the Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:2.5) sample [28,29]. These results suggest that the segregation of the dopants phase from the crystal lattice of magnetite at higher atomic amounts of Ce and Co. In order to ensure the incorporation of Ce and Co ions into magnetite structure, lattice parameter values are calculated, since it is highly responsive to the dopants concentration in the host matrix (iron oxide). Table 1 reported the corresponding lattice parameter values for all reduced samples. It is shown that the lattice parameter increased with the increase of both Ce from 0.5 to 1.0 and Co from 0.5 to 1.5 atomic contents in the catalyst. As is known, the radius of Fe3+ (0.67Å) ion is smaller than that of Ce4+ (0.97Å) and Co2+ (0.82Å) dopant ions [30]. Thus, the lattice expansion could be related to the substitution of smaller Fe3+ by larger Ce4+ and Co2+ ions in the magnetite lattice. These results also confirm that Ce and Co form a homogeneous intermetallic mixture with iron oxide (CeOFeOCo solid solution) in the catalyst as a result of the synergistic interaction between Fe and dopants which is strong at Fe/Ce/Co atomic ratio of 10:1:1.5. However, the lattice parameter decreases with further increase in the Ce (from 1.0 to 1.5 and 2.0) and Co (from 1.5 to 2.0 and 2.5) atomic concentrations. This result implies the segregation of cerium and cobalt ions due to the weak interaction between Fe and dopants and hence the limited solubility of Ce and Co in the magnetite matrix. All these findings are also evidenced from (311) peak that shifts to lower angle as the atomic content of Ce and Co increases from 0.5 to 1.0 and 0.5 to 1.5, respectively (see the inset in Fig. 4) and then moves to higher angle with further increasing the Ce and Co atomic concentrations (see the inset in Fig. 4). Owing to the difference in the ionic sizes of Fe and dopants, the substitution of magnetite lattice by Ce and Co could lead to structural distortion with oxygen vacancies, which induces lattice strain in the Fe/Ce/Co catalysts. The lattice strain in all the reduced catalysts was calculated by Williamson-Hall plots and the obtained values are listed in Table 1. It can be seen that the lattice strain increases with the increase in both Ce and Co atomic contents and eventually reaches a maximum in the Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5) catalyst (0.0104). However, further increasing the atomic amount of Ce from 1 to 1.5 and 2.0 and Co from 1.5 to 2.0 and 2.5 led to decreased lattice strain. Meanwhile, the crystallite size (Table 1), which is estimated using the Scherer equation, is decreased until the Ce and Co atomic contents reached to 1.0 and 1.5, respectively, and then increased with further increasing the dopants concentration. This phenomenon also relates to broadened diffraction peaks in the Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5) compared to the other catalysts. As mentioned before, this can be again due to the strong synergistic interaction between Fe and dopants thereby maximum replacement of Fe ions with the Ce and Co dopants in the catalyst at Fe/Ce/Co atomic ratio of 10:1:1.5 among the other samples. The elemental composition of each metal in the fresh Fe/Ce/Co catalysts was determined by EDX analysis and the results are reported in Table S1 and Fig. S3. The obtained spectra indicated the presence of Fe, Ce, and Co elements in all the catalysts (Fig. S3) and their atomic compositions were in agreement with the actual contents used for synthesis. These findings demonstrated good control of the elements composition by co-precipitation method. 3.3 Raman spectroscopy The Raman spectroscopy is an important tool for the study of amorphous or poor crystalline materials that cannot be detected by XRD. Since the fresh Fe/Ce/Co samples were not able to analyze by XRD, the crystalline structure of fresh catalysts was investigated by Raman spectroscopy which is dominated by oxygen lattice vibrations and sensitive to the crystalline symmetry [26]. The deconvoluted Raman spectra of the fresh Fe/Ce/Co catalysts with different Co and Ce atomic contents are displayed in Fig. 5 . Seven phonon bands (2A1g and 5Eg) can be detectable in the Raman spectra of pure hematite where A1g and Eg correspond to symmetric stretch of oxygen atoms along FeO bonds and symmetric bend of oxygen with respect to Fe, respectively [31–33]. It is evident that all catalysts showed the five of the seven Raman-active modes of hematite which can be indexed with the symmetries of A1g(1), A1g(2), Eg(2), Eg(4), and Eg(5). However, the Eg(1) and Eg(3) bands appear as shoulders on the A1g(1) and Eg(2) peaks, respectively, and are often not well resolved at room temperature [24,33–36]. These findings confirm the presence of the hematite phase in all the fresh Fe/Ce/Co catalysts which are in agreement with previous studies [36,37]. An additional peak is seen in the region of 658–676cm−1 for all the samples can be attributed to the IR-active Eu(LO) vibration mode which is Raman-inactive in the pristine hematite lattice [36,38]. Several research groups have reported that the Raman forbidden Eu(LO) feature becomes active in doped hematite oxides as a result of symmetry breaking. This arises from the replacement of iron with dopant elements which would lead to a significant lattice distortion [36,38–41]. Hence, the emergence of Raman-inactive Eu(LO) mode in the Fe/Ce/Co catalysts should be allocated to the lattice disorder induced by the incorporation of Ce and Co into hematite matrix. There are two possible reasons for the symmetry reduction (formation of lattice disorder) in the Fe/Ce/Co catalysts; the first is discussed in terms of changes in the oxygen stoichiometry upon replacement of Fe3+ in the hematite lattice by Ce4+ and Co2+ ions. The second may be the changes in the Fe3+ to Fe2+ stoichiometry that could ensure the electroneutrality of the lattice upon Fe3+ substitution by Ce4+ and Co2+ [31]. Both may be believed as contributing to the formation of lattice disorder in the Ce- and Co-modified hematite samples and thus, to their WGS performance. The lattice disorder can also be quantified by the relative integrated peak area ratio of the Eu(LO) to Eg(5) and corresponding values are presented in Table 2 . The Eu(LO)/Eg(5) ratio increases with increase in the Co and Ce atomic contents and it reaches a maximum value (2.25) in the catalyst at Fe/Ce/Co atomic ratio of 10:1:1.5. This result implies that the Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5) catalyst shows the highest lattice disorder among all other samples which could be related to the existence of a strong synergistic interaction between the Fe and dopants in its structure. However, the trend in Eu(LO)/Eg(5) ratio appears to be fully reversible, as further increasing the Ce and Co atomic concentrations cause the lattice disorder to decrease. This obviously suggests a reduction in the lattice disorder at higher atomic amounts of Ce and Co in the catalyst due to weak interaction between Fe and dopants. Besides to the Eu(LO) band, the other strong feature at a higher wave number (1254–1294cm−1) in all the catalysts is usually ascribed to second harmonic vibration (overtone or second order scattering) [42]. According to the literature, this mode originates either from magnon–magnon (M–M) scattering due to canted antiferromagnetic spin sites or from phonon–phonon (P–P) scattering because of lattice disorder [36,43,44]. However, the wave number of this peak is not exactly twice of the frequency of IR-active Eu(LO) (lattice disorder) mode in all the catalysts. This clearly indicates that the M–M scattering effect is responsible for the appearance of the band in the region of 1254–1294cm−1. 3.4 H2-temperature programmed reduction The reducibility of the catalyst is a key controlling parameter for WGS reaction as it depends on the redox property of the catalytic material. Thus, H2-TPR measurement was performed to investigate the reduction behavior of fresh Fe/Ce/Co catalysts and the profiles obtained at different Ce and Co atomic contents are shown in Fig. 6 a and b, respectively. The reduction patterns were deconvoluted to resolve the reducibility of all components in the samples. All the catalysts exhibited six reduction peaks, labelled as α, β, γ, δ, ε, and ϕ. The reducibility of pure Fe2O3 is commonly reported by three peaks, corresponding to the stepwise reduction of hematite to metallic Fe through Fe3O4/FeO as intermediates (Fe2O3 →Fe3O4 →FeO→Fe) [45–47]. Accordingly, the three reduction peaks denoted as α, δ, and ε in the profiles of the Fe/Ce/Co ternary oxide catalysts could be sequentially assigned to the reduction of Fe2O3 →Fe3O4, Fe3O4 →FeO, and FeO→Fe, respectively [13–16,47,48]. Meanwhile, the β, γ, and ϕ peaks can be ascribed to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO [13–15], surface, and bulk CeO2 [26,27], respectively. Among all the phase transitions of iron oxide, the reduction of hematite to magnetite is indispensable in the present study because magnetite phase regarded as the active phase for WGS [13–16,49]. It can be seen that the position of hematite to magnetite reduction peak obviously shift to lower temperature either with an increase of Co atomic composition from 0.5 to 1.5 (at constant Ce atomic content of 1.0) or with an increase of Ce atomic amount from 0.5 to 1.0 (at constant Co atomic content of 1.5) in the catalyst. However, the further increment in Co atomic amount to 2.0 and 2.5 or Ce atomic content to 1.5 and 2.0, this reduction peak shifted to higher temperatures. It is clear that the incorporation Ce and Co into the iron oxide lattice can significantly alter the reduction temperature for Fe2O3 to Fe3O4 transition. A similar trend in shifting the reduction temperatures have also reported by Wang et al. [47] and Shao et al. [50] in the case of the FexCe1−xO2−δ and Co-FeOx catalysts, respectively. To make it more intuitive to understand the effect of Co and Ce atomic contents on the reducibility of Fe/Ce/Co samples, the degree of reduction for the Fe2O3 to Fe3O4 transition was also determined from the integrated peak area. Interestingly, the catalyst at a Fe/Ce/Co atomic ratio of 10:1:1.5 shows the highest degree of reduction for Fe2O3 to Fe3O4 transition among other samples. These facts (lowest reduction temperature and highest degree of reduction of Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5)) can be attributed to the elevated synergistic interaction between dopant species (Ce and Co) and the Fe2O3 in the catalyst. Moreover, this synergistic interaction driven by the formation of CeOFeOCo bonds, in which Ce4+/Ce3+ and Co2+/Co3+ redox couples could promote the Fe3+/Fe2+ redox cycle through the redox equilibrium of 2Fe3+ +Ce3+ +Co2+ ↔2Fe2+ +Ce4+ +Co3+. The strong facilitation of the Fe3+/Fe2+ redox cycle by Ce3+/Ce4+ and Co2+/Co3+ redox couples in the Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5) catalyst will also be proven by XPS results. The highest reducibility of the Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5) catalyst can be further ascribed to its largest stress among the other samples which was authenticated from XRD results. 3.5 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy XPS spectra were utilized to characterize the chemical environment of Fe, Ce, Co, and O on the surface of reduced catalysts. All spectra were first corrected with the C 1s line at 284.6eV. Fig. 7 a and b shows the Fe 2p XPS spectra of reduced Fe/Ce/Co catalysts at different Co and Ce atomic contents. A doublet observed for all the reduced catalysts in the region of 710.6–710.8eV and 723.9–724.3eV with a spin–orbit separation of 13.3–13.5eV corresponds to Fe 2p electrons for Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2 states, respectively. These results demonstrate the formation of Fe3O4 phase during the reduction process [51–53]. In addition, there was no peak at ∼706.6eV, which can be attributed to over reduction of magnetite to a metallic iron phase [22,51]. This result clearly indicates the good stability of the samples during the reduction process. In order to identify the oxidation state of Fe ions on the surface of reduced catalysts, the Fe 2p spectra were deconvoluted using the Gaussian–Lorentzian line shape and the fitting procedure was given elsewhere [24]. The deconvolution results show that the peak of Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2 core-level electrons split into two components in all the catalysts. Especially, the peaks of Fe 2p3/2 state is centered in the region of 710.0–710.6eV and 711.8–712.4eV, which can be assigned to Fe2+ and Fe3+ oxidation states, respectively [54–57]. Thus, the mixed Fe3+/2+ valence states in the Fe 2p spectra has again confirmed the presence of Fe3O4 phase in all reduced catalysts, which is consistent with XRD results. Moreover, a satellite peak observed at ∼717.3–718.7eV for all samples. In general, the Fe 2p XPS spectrum of stoichiometric Fe3O4 species with the Fe3+/Fe2+ ratio of 2:1 does not have a satellite structure [52,58,59]. Hence, the emergence of satellite peak indicates the formation of nonstoichiometric magnetite phase in the reduced samples. This could be arises due to the substitution of Fe3O4 crystal lattice with the Co and Ce ions [60,61]. A further confirmation for co-doped magnetite was obtained from a comparison of the Fe3+/Fe2+ ratio on the surface of reduced catalysts. Although Fe3+ and Fe2+ ions were distinguishable by Fe 2p spectra, the presence of satellite peak hindered the accurate estimation of the Fe3+/Fe2+ ratio as it may partially overlap with the main (Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2) peaks [52,62]. Therefore, the Fe 3p XPS spectra are used in the present study for the assessment of Fe3+/Fe2+ ratio on the surface of samples. The deconvolution of Fe 3p could be separated into two components (Fig. 7c and d) in which the peak at a lower binding energy corresponding to Fe2+ state and the peak at higher binding energy could be related to Fe3+ ion. The relative surface Fe3+/Fe2+ ratio for each sample was calculated using the ratio of the integrated area of Fe3+ peak to the integrated area of Fe2+ peak and the corresponding values are summarized in Table 2. It can be seen that the obtained ratio of Fe3+/Fe2+ for all sample is in the region of 1.51–1.87 (Table 2), which is lower than that anticipated for stoichiometric Fe3O4 (Fe3+/Fe2+ =2). This fact again reveals that some of Fe ions in the magnetite lattice are replaced by Co and Ce ions, which is in line with XRD results. Interestingly, the Fe3+/Fe2+ ratio on the surface of the Fe/Ce/Co catalyst decreased with an increase in either the Co atomic content to 1.5 or the Ce atomic amount to 1.0. In addition, it can be expected that further increasing of Ce and Co atomic concentration in the catalyst then will lead to the additional reduction in the surface Fe3+/Fe2+ ratio. However, the Fe3+/Fe2+ ratio increased with further increase in both the Co and Ce atomic compositions. A similar trend was also observed by Li et al. [63], in which the surface Fe2+ content is gradually increased with decreasing Fe/W molar ratio (or increasing W molar content), reaching a maximum of 11.35% at Fe/W molar ratio of 5.0, then reducing to 7.93% with further decreasing the Fe/W molar ratio to 1.0. These results suggest that the both Co and Ce promoters have the ability to facilitate the surface Fe3+/Fe2+ redox cycle through the synergistic interaction between Fe and dopant ions. The Fe-Ce-Co synergy might be achieved by the combined redox behavior of iron (Fe3+/Fe2+), cerium (Ce4+/Ce3+), and cobalt (Co3+/Co2+) cations. In addition, the quantity of the Fe3+/Fe2+ ratio directly reflects the promotion of Fe3+ ↔Fe2+ redox cycle with Ce4+/Ce3+ and Co3+/Co2+ redox couples, since a lower Fe3+/Fe2+ ratio being associated with a more facilitated Fe3+ ↔Fe2+ redox cycle over the catalyst. Hence, these findings also confirm the greater facilitation of Fe3+/Fe2+ redox couple or stronger synergistic effect between Fe and dopants on the surface of Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5) catalyst as it exhibits the lowest quantity of Fe3+/Fe2+ ratio among other samples. All these facts correlate well with the H2-TPR results, which showed the shift toward lower reduction temperatures with the incorporation of Co and Ce up to 1.5 and 1.0, respectively. Fig. 8 a and b show the Ce 3d core level XPS spectra for reduced Fe/Ce/Co catalysts at different Co and Ce atomic contents, respectively. The deconvolution of the Ce 3d XPS spectra results in four spin–orbit-split doublets, one of which (u′, v′) is represented 4f1 (Ce3+ ions) configurations in the photoemission final state, while the rest ((u, v), (u″, v″) (u‴, v‴)) assigned to 4f0 (Ce4+ species) configurations [24,64]. Hence, the observed four doublet peaks are characteristic for the coexistence of Ce4+ and Ce3+ ions on the surface of all reduced Fe/Ce/Co catalysts. The Co 2p3/2 XPS spectra of all reduced Fe/Ce/Co catalysts displayed in Fig. 8c and d. To assess the oxidation states of cobalt on the surface of reduced catalysts, the XPS of Co 2p3/2 region can be fitted into three contributions. The first two main peaks located in the region of 781.0–782.9eV and 784.8–786.9eV are assigned to Co3+ and Co2+ ions, respectively [21,65]. The third peak at around 788.1–791.0eV corresponds to satellite peak of Co 2p3/2 which is further indicative of Co2+ species [66]. The existence of Ce3+, Ce4+, Co2+, and Co3+ states unambiguously evidence the synergistic interaction between Fe and dopants in the catalysts through the redox equilibrium of 2Fe3+ +Ce3+ +Co2+ ↔2Fe2+ +Ce4+ +Co3+ which is corroborated with Fe XPS results. The XPS spectra of the O 1s core level for all reduced samples are presented in Fig. S4. It can be seen that all catalysts exhibit an asymmetric O 1s peak due to the presence of different types of surface oxygen ions, which causes the spectrum deconvoluted into three components. The first peak at lower binding energy (529.6–530.3eV, O′) is ascribed to lattice oxygen of the surface magnetite phase [67]. The second peak in the region of 530.4–532.1eV (O″) corresponds to surface adsorbed oxygen species, while the third peak in the region of 532.3–533.5eV (O‴) could be associated with weakly bonded oxygen species like molecular water or carbonate species on the surface of catalysts [68,69]. 3.6 Correlation of catalytic performance with surface/structural properties As mentioned above, it is clearly found that the HT-WGS performance of Fe/Ce/Co catalyst can be regulated by the both Co and Ce atomic contents, which should be connected with the different structural properties. Generally, the surface area of the catalyst plays a crucial role in the WGS as it can expose active sites which are directly promoted the catalytic reaction. The surface area (determined from BET analysis) of the reduced Fe/Ce/Co catalyst increases with the following trend: Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:0.5)<Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1)<Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5)>Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:2)>Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:2.5) and Fe/Ce/Co (10:0.5:1.5)<Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5)>Fe/Ce/Co (10:1.5:1.5)>Fe/Ce/Co (10:2:1.5) (Table 2). This order indicated that increase in the atomic content of Co from 0.5 to 1.5 and Ce from 0.5 to 1.0, increased the BET surface area while further increase in both the atomic concentrations caused loss of surface area. Meshkani et al. [23], observed that the WGS activity of Fe-Al-Cu catalyst was linearly related to its surface area at different Fe/Cu ratios and above 400°C. Similarly, the trend in the surface area of Fe/Ce/Co catalysts is directly correlated with their catalytic performance. Hence, it can be concluded that surface area is one of the key parameters for the variation in WGS activity of the Fe/Ce/Co catalyst with different Co and Ce atomic contents. In other words, the highest surface area of Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5) catalyst could be responsible for its best activity among the other samples. Despite the reaction mechanism, the dissociation of H2O molecules is considered as a rate determining step in the WGS [70,71]. The stress associated with the defect sites in the catalyst could facilitate the dissociation of water to form OH/H2 and O2− anions. To ensure the relationship between the WGS activity and stress of the catalyst, the variation in lattice strain (from XRD), lattice disorder (from Raman results), and CO conversion rate of Fe/Ce/Co catalysts with different Co and Ce atomic contents is plotted in Fig. 9 . It could be found that the CO conversion rate is directly related to the magnitude of lattice strain/disorder in the catalysts. This means that the activity of Fe/Ce/Co catalysts increased with an increase in the lattice strain/disorder. This phenomenon unambiguously revealed that the lattice strain/disorder could play the decisive role in the enhanced WGS activity. Therefore, the greatest catalytic performance of Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5) should be ascribed to its highest lattice strain/disorder among the other catalysts. Besides the role of lattice distortion, it has been reported that the WGS reaction requires the participation of surface Fe3+/Fe2+ redox couple over iron-based catalysts [12,72]. The correlation between the CO conversion rate in WGS and the relative Fe3+/Fe2+ ratio (from XPS analysis) was demonstrated in Fig. 9. It can be found that the activity increases with decreasing the quantity of Fe3+/Fe2+ ratio on the surface of the catalyst. This finding obviously suggests that the surface Fe3+/Fe2+ redox pair could play a crucial role in promoting the HT-WGS reaction. According to XPS results, the lower amount of Fe3+/Fe2+ ratio on a catalyst surface indicates its highly facilitated Fe3+ ↔Fe2+ redox cycle with Ce4+/Ce3+ and Co3+/Co2+ redox couples. In addition, the more facilitated Fe3+/Fe2+ redox cycle could accelerate the CO oxidation rate with reduction of Fe3+ to Fe2+, followed by the H2O dissociation rate with reoxidation of Fe2+ to Fe3+. Therefore, it can be concluded that the better WGS performance of the Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5) was ascribed to its greatly facilitated Fe3+/Fe2+ redox couple among the other catalysts. This phenomenon is in agreement with H2-TPR results in which the Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5) catalyst shows the lower reduction temperature (Fig. 6) and a higher degree of reduction for hematite to magnetite transition (Table 2) among the other samples. These results are also in harmony with the fact that the redox mechanism becomes dominant in the HT-WGS on Fe-based catalysts. To further understand the best activity of Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5) catalyst, the TEM images, and corresponding particle size distributions of the catalyst in fresh, activated, and spent states were compared in Fig. 10 , respectively. The particles with no distinctive shapes (irregular morphology) can be clearly identified in all states of the catalyst. It can be seen that the catalyst was seriously agglomerated in a fresh state. This could be attributed to the small particle size of the catalyst which was about 3.76nm with a standard deviation of ±0.53nm (Fig. 10a). This is also in accordance with our XRD results, in which the fresh catalyst did not show the diffraction lines due to its very small particle size less than 5.0nm that was beyond the detection capability of the instrument. The narrow size distribution of particles probably results from the fast and homogeneous reactions during the mixing under the coprecipitation process. Surprisingly, the catalyst shows the scattered particles morphology upon reduction with process gas and the particles size distribution is significantly increased with an average particle size of 15.4±3.2nm (Fig. 10b). This reduction induces increased particle size could be ascribed to better crystallization during the activation process. The average particle size of activated catalyst is also well matched with the crystalline size estimated from the XRD, which indicates that each individual particle consist of a single crystal [73]. However, the average size of the particles was slightly increased even after WGS which was about 18.4±2.6nm (Fig. 10c) and 19.8±2.6nm (Fig. 10d) at steam to CO ratios of 3.5 and 1.5, respectively. Therefore, the small variation in the particle size distribution from activated to spent states suggests the good thermal stability of the catalyst which is the typical feature for the best activity of Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5). The time on stream stability (TOS) of Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5) catalyst was further verified by characterizing the spent catalyst using TEM and XPS techniques. Fig. 11 a and b represent the TEM images and particle size distributions of the spent catalyst for 100h at both steam to CO ratios of 3.5 and 1.5, respectively. Interestingly, the spent catalyst exhibits the particles of spherical shapes at both steam to CO ratios unlike the reduced catalyst that shows irregular morphology. This distinct morphology of the spent catalyst even after 100h of reaction is an important characteristic for its good time on stream stability. Furthermore, the spent catalyst exhibits the average particle size of 18.1±1.2nm and 19.2±2.4nm at steam to CO ratios of 3.5 and 1.5, respectively (Fig. 11a and b). Thus, there was not much change in the particle size of the spent catalyst even after TOS study compared to the reduced one which was about 15.4±3.2nm. These findings demonstrate that the strong interaction between Fe and dopant (Co and Ce) cations in the Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5) catalyst could effectively inhibit the sintering of particles during WGS which is accountable for its stable activity for a period of 100h. The core level Fe 2p and Fe 3p XPS spectra of Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5) catalyst after 100h of reaction at steam to CO ratios of 3.5 and 1.5 were shown in Fig. 11c and d. Similar to the reduced catalyst, Fe 2p spectrum of the spent catalyst shows the peaks corresponding to Fe3+ and Fe2+ states along with satellite peak in the region of 717.8–718.0eV at both steam to CO ratios. In addition, the spent catalyst could not display the feature at ∼706.6eV that represents the metallic Fe phase [22,51]. Therefore, the catalyst remains in the Fe3O4 phase even after the TOS study. The surface Fe3+/Fe2+ ratio (calculated from the Fe 3p spectra) on the Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5) catalyst were 1.55 and 1.48 after 100h of the reaction at steam to CO ratio of 3.5 and 1.5, respectively. Fascinatingly, Fe 3p analysis of the spent catalyst indicates no appreciable changes in the surface Fe3+/Fe2+ ratio from the reduced catalyst that exhibits the ratio of 1.51. All these results illustrate that the strong interaction between Fe and dopant (Co and Ce) cations in the catalyst not only improved thermal stability but also endowed excellent structural stability during TOS study. 4 Conclusions In summary, a series of Fe/Ce/Co catalysts were prepared by the facile co-precipitation method and studied the effect of both Co and Ce atomic concentrations on their physicochemical and catalytic performance for HT-WGS reaction. Among the catalyst with other Co and Ce atomic contents, the Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5) catalyst exhibited the highest CO conversion in HT-WGS. The catalyst also displayed a stable catalytic performance for 100h of time on stream. The XRD, Raman, BET, H2-TPR, and XPS characterizations showed substantial changes in the structural and surface properties of the Fe/Ce/Co catalysts as a function of both Co and Ce doping. The HT-WGS activity was closely associated with the surface area, lattice strain/disorder, reducibility, and surface Fe3+/Fe2+ redox couple of the Fe/Ce/Co catalysts. The better catalytic performance of Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5) could be explained by the strong synergistic effect between Fe and dopants (Co and Ce) in the catalyst that could provide high surface area and lattice strain/disorder as well as the efficient Fe3+ ↔Fe2+ redox ability. The TEM and XPS analysis further demonstrated that there was no obvious change in the particle size and Fe3+/Fe2+ redox pair of the spent Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5) catalyst even after 100h of reaction, respectively, compared to the reduced one. All these findings provide valuable insights into the design of highly efficient Cr-free Fe-based catalysts for HT-WGS. coredata.dc:description: A set of Fe/Ce/Co ferrite spinels was synthesized and characterized to investigate the effect of Ce and Co atomic contents in the catalyst on the high-temperature water-gas shift (HT-WGS) performance. It was found that both the Ce and Co atomic compositions in the Fe/Ce/Co catalyst have a significant influence on the surface and structural properties and thereby HT-WGS activity. The Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5) exhibited the best activity owing to preferable properties among the catalysts with other Ce and Co atomic contents. Besides, it showed an excellent time-on-stream (TOS) stability in HT-WGS for 100h of reaction even at lower steam to CO ratio of 1.5. XRD results suggested that Ce and Co co-doping could make the lattice strain in the magnetite lattice because of difference in the ionic sizes of Fe and dopants. Raman spectroscopy demonstrated that the lattice disorder was introduced with the addition of Ce and Co. The magnitude of the lattice strain/disorder depends on the promoters’ (Ce and Co) atomic composition in the catalyst. Our H2-TPR findings indicate that the degree of reduction for hematite-to-magnetite conversion increased until the Ce and Co atomic concentration reached to 1.0 and 1.5, respectively. The XPS analysis proves that both Ce and Co as dopants have the ability to facilitate the surface Fe3+ ↔Fe2+ redox cycle over the catalysts because of their redox nature (Ce4+/Ce3+, Co2+/Co3+). We observed the changes in the quantity of surface Fe3+/Fe2+ ratio as a function of the Ce and Co atomic contents. The results also revealed that the surface area, lattice strain/disorder, reducibility, and surface Fe3+/Fe2+ redox pair were the decisive factors for the HT-WGS reaction. A combination of techniques demonstrated that there is a strong synergistic interaction between Fe and dopants (Ce and Co) in the Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5) which could enhance its surface area, lattice strain/disorder, surface Fe3+/Fe2+ redox capability, and thus leading to the elevated HT-WGS activity among other catalysts. XPS investigations on the spent Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5) after 100h of reaction show that the catalyst remains in magnetite phase like the reduced one and is not reduced or oxidized during reaction. Our TEM images confirm that the Fe/Ce/Co (10:1:1.5) catalyst particles are not agglomerating/sintering during the TOS study which is an important characteristic for its long term stability.
